title: 103_s1178
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Federal Effectiveness Act" and pertains to the Great Lakes Research Council. The "Great Lakes Federal Effectiveness Act" establishes the Great Lakes Research Council to advise and coordinate federal research activities for ecosystem protection in the Great Lakes. The Council is tasked with assessing research needs, federal expertise, and making recommendations for fulfilling the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement goals. The Great Lakes Research Council advises on federal research activities for ecosystem protection in the Great Lakes. It identifies research priorities, participates in meetings, recommends data collection protocols, establishes a data base, and ensures timely dissemination of research findings. The Great Lakes Research Council is comprised of research managers from various federal agencies and may include non-Federal employees as ex officio members. The Chairperson is elected by the members for a two-year term, with a limit of two consecutive terms. Members are entitled to compensation while performing official duties. Members of the Great Lakes Research Council are entitled to compensation for travel expenses while performing official duties. Federal agencies cooperating with the Council must implement recommendations, provide necessary resources, and furnish data upon request. The Great Lakes Research Council invites the International Joint Commission to coordinate activities and may reimburse costs. The Act does not affect the authority of federal agencies for Great Lakes research. The Act defines key terms such as "Council" as the Great Lakes Research Council, "Great Lakes" including specific bodies of water, "Great Lakes research" as scientific application in the ecosystem, and "Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement" as a bilateral agreement between the US and Canada.
